instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPBUSS_G3H: What is PPBUSS_G3H? This is a typo of PPBUS_G3H When you see PPBUSS_G3H, assume they meant to type PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.R7105: What is R7105? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .

threads.title: 829-3437 not power up
threads.message:
Have a [URL="tel:<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>"]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>[/URL] logic board that won't power up.
have orange light on magsafe.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> only give 4,35V
<TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> pin2 16,58

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>

1 ) 0v
2 ) 16,26v
3 ) 4.41v
9 ) 0,036v
12 ) 3.39v
13 ) 3.39v
14 ) 3.36v
17) 4.12v
18) 4.12v
15 ) 0.028v
19 ) 5.158v
20 ) 5.163v
26 ) 16.35v
27) 16.59v
28) 16.59v

have no history on it

threads.title: 829-3437 not power up
threads.message: Remove F7140 and see if <SIGNAL>PPBUSS_G3H</SIGNAL> comes up???

threads.title: 829-3437 not power up
threads.message: sounds like buck converter problem between <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>. i would check for short to ground on pin7 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>, if no short then change <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>, then <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. I'm betting <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is not working properly.

threads.title: 829-3437 not power up
threads.message:
What's the resistance between pins 17/18 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>?

What's the resistance between pins 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>? 

What is the resistance of <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR>? 

Will this work from a charged battery?

threads.title: 829-3437 not power up
threads.message:
What's the resistance between pins 17/18 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>? resistance between pins 17/18 is 3,3ohm

What's the resistance between pins 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>? resistance between pins 27/28 is 20,2ohm

What is the resistance of <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR>? resistance of <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> is fuck hole on. after replace with new i have 20.4ohm

Will this work from a charged battery? Will charge the battery and see

<TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> pin 7 is 0.120 in diode mode (im not sure if i measured on right pin, because as i see pin 7 is under the chip but i think that is tecsame pin on the side off it)

threads.title: 829-3437 not power up
threads.message: If <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> was bad <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> will be dead too. Also <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> will probably be dead again if you did not change <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: 829-3437 not power up
threads.message:
Yes it was a hole in <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> and it was waiving someting around 90 ohm 



<RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> still gives 20.40 ohm so i tray to replace <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> again
